summary: An email exchange between FBI personnel regarding securing seats for three FBI officials (ADIC and SAC) to attend an Epstein hearing scheduled for the following day (August 27, 2019). The email originates from an FBI squad focused on Crimes Against Children/Human Trafficking.

persons.name: ADIC
persons.role: FBI official (likely Assistant Director in Charge)
persons.context: An FBI official who, along with SAC, wishes to attend the Epstein hearing. The email sender is requesting seats for them.

persons.name: SAC
persons.role: FBI official (likely Special Agent in Charge)
persons.context: An FBI official who, along with ADIC, wishes to attend the Epstein hearing. The email sender is requesting seats for them.

persons.name: SSA - Squad C-20
persons.context: The sender of the original email, identified as part of the FBI New York field office's Crimes Against Children/Human Trafficking squad, requesting seats for ADIC and SAC at the hearing.

connections.description: Both are FBI officials whose attendance at the Epstein hearing is being coordinated together by the email sender.
The SSA is making arrangements for the ADIC to attend the hearing, indicating a subordinate/superior or inter-office professional relationship.
The SSA is making arrangements for the SAC to attend the hearing, indicating a subordinate/superior or inter-office professional relationship.

events.title: Epstein hearing
events.description: A court hearing related to Jeffrey Epstein. The email is sent the day prior to arrange FBI attendance.

keyFacts: The email is dated August 26, 2019, the day before a scheduled Epstein hearing.
High-level FBI officials (ADIC and SAC) sought to attend the Epstein hearing, indicating significant law enforcement interest.
The request originates from the FBI's New York-based Crimes Against Children/Human Trafficking squad (C-20), directly linking the hearing to their investigative purview.
The email shows internal FBI coordination to secure seating for their personnel at a high-profile court proceeding.
